author: paulhauner
content:
With the current CL implementation of the builder API, all blocks must be verified by a local EE before they are attested to. This prevents finalization of invalid blocks.

FB's original approach was to be a "middleware", where they become the canonical source of truth for payload validity for CLs. In such a scenario it's trivial for FB to finalize an invalid payload.

We're looking at the choice between (a) allowing FB to finalize whatever they want and (b) having more FB blocks on the network. I don't claim that anything here is "strictly" better or worse with CL integration of the builder API and I would be very cautious about anyone doing so.

author: darius510
content: I don't agree with this. The choice of which mining pool to use is fluid, anyone can switch to another one with relative ease. It's nothing more than a temporary arrangement of convenience. If some mining pools begin to censor it is relatively easy for a miner to switch to another and the offending pool loses its hashrate and power to censor very rapidly. For example if Ethermine decides to start censoring the US sanctions list, it only takes a few seconds for a miner to switch to a non-compliant non-US based pool. And pools aside, with 15 second blocks, solo mining on ETH is still viable even for small miners and their identity is easily hidden with VPNs. Whereas PoS staking pools are generally custodians that hold the keys. Nevermind the fact that withdrawals aren't even enabled yet, but users will generally only be able to request a withdrawal and then if they have <32ETH (which is a very significant amount of money right now) they face the very questionable choice of whether they're willing to trust some off-shore custodian with their stake.  With 32ETH they can solo stake, but if they want to validate those censored blocks they then run the risk of committing financial crimes themselves, and the withdrawal of their stake from the KYCed custodian draws a straight line back to their real world identity - making this a very, very bad idea for someone who doesn't want to risk federal prison. PoW miners can't be tracked like that. Through chain analytics its not going to be that difficult to identify solo stakers based on transactions made many years ago. With respect, PoS absolutely makes this condition worse. Mining pools hold tenuous power here, but small stakers NEED staking pools in a way that miners don't, and in this context, a solo staker is going to be far more incentivized to adhere to sanctions than a solo miner.
When will the merge happen?

Should the API be removed/hidden in the merge releases until a non-censoring relay is found?  A relay will need heavy DDoS protection so it may not be so easy/cheap to spin one up...

I don't think the client devs/EF should underestimate the power they have at least in the short term by setting defaults/communicating recommendations.

It seems to me that not having "democratic" MEV at the merge is worth it to buy the ecosystem some time to enshrine a relay/builder that is in line with Ethereum's ethos.  If a censoring relay is installed as the default at the merge it will be significantly harder to change later.
